text: It is to be with him, and he is to read it all the days of his life so that he may learn to revere the Lord his God and follow carefully all the words of this law and these decrees
speaker: Narrator

text: and not consider himself better than his fellow Israelites and turn from the law to the right or to the left. Then he and his descendants will reign a long time over his kingdom in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levitical priests – indeed, the whole tribe of Levi – are to have no land allotted to them or any inheritance with Israel. They shall live on the food offerings presented to the Lord, for that is their inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall have no inheritance among their fellow Israelites; the Lord is their inheritance, as he promised them.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the share due to the priests from the people who sacrifice a bull or a sheep: the shoulder, the internal organs and the meat from the head.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to give them the firstfruits of your corn, new wine and olive oil, and the first wool from the shearing of your sheep,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the Lord your God has chosen them and their descendants out of all your tribes to stand and minister in the Lord’s name always.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a Levite moves from one of your towns anywhere in Israel where he is living, and comes in all earnestness to the place the Lord will choose,
speaker: Narrator

text: he may minister in the name of the Lord his God like all his fellow Levites who serve there in the presence of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to share equally in their benefits even though he has received money from the sale of family possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you enter the land the Lord your God is giving you, do not learn to imitate the detestable ways of the nations there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let no one be found among you who sacrifices their son or daughter in the fire, who practises divination or sorcery, interprets omens, engages in witchcraft,
speaker: Narrator

text: or casts spells, or who is a medium or spiritist or who consults the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who does these things is detestable to the Lord; because of these same detestable practices the Lord your God will drive out those nations before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must be blameless before the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The nations you will dispossess listen to those who practise sorcery or divination. But as for you, the Lord your God has not permitted you to do so.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will raise up for you a prophet like me from among you, from your fellow Israelites. You must listen to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this is what you asked of the Lord your God at Horeb on the day of the assembly when you said, ‘Let us not hear the voice of the Lord our God nor see this great fire any more, or we will die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to me: ‘What they say is good.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will raise up for them a prophet like you from among their fellow Israelites, and I will put my words in his mouth. He will tell them everything I command him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself will call to account anyone who does not listen to my words that the prophet speaks in my name.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a prophet who presumes to speak in my name anything I have not commanded, or a prophet who speaks in the name of other gods, is to be put to death.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You may say to yourselves, ‘How can we know when a message has not been spoken by the Lord?’
speaker: Narrator

text: If what a prophet proclaims in the name of the Lord does not take place or come true, that is a message the Lord has not spoken. That prophet has spoken presumptuously, so do not be alarmed.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God has destroyed the nations whose land he is giving you, and when you have driven them out and settled in their towns and houses,
speaker: Narrator

text: then set aside for yourselves three cities in the land the Lord your God is giving you to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: Determine the distances involved and divide into three parts the land the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance, so that a person who kills someone may flee for refuge to one of these cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the rule concerning anyone who kills a person and flees there for safety – anyone who kills a neighbour unintentionally, without malice aforethought.
speaker: Narrator

text: For instance, a man may go into the forest with his neighbour to cut wood, and as he swings his axe to fell a tree, the head may fly off and hit his neighbour and kill him. That man may flee to one of these cities and save his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, the avenger of blood might pursue him in a rage, overtake him if the distance is too great, and kill him even though he is not deserving of death, since he did it to his neighbour without malice aforethought.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is why I command you to set aside for yourselves three cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the Lord your God enlarges your territory, as he promised on oath to your ancestors, and gives you the whole land he promised them,
speaker: Narrator

text: because you carefully follow all these laws I command you today – to love the Lord your God and to walk always in obedience to him – then you are to set aside three more cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this so that innocent blood will not be shed in your land, which the Lord your God is giving you as your inheritance, and so that you will not be guilty of bloodshed.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if out of hate someone lies in wait, assaults and kills a neighbour, and then flees to one of these cities,
speaker: Narrator

text: the killer shall be sent for by the town elders, be brought back from the city, and be handed over to the avenger of blood to die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Show no pity. You must purge from Israel the guilt of shedding innocent blood, so that it may go well with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not move your neighbour’s boundary stone set up by your predecessors in the inheritance you receive in the land the Lord your God is giving you to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: One witness is not enough to convict anyone accused of any crime or offence they may have committed. A matter must be established by the testimony of two or three witnesses.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a malicious witness takes the stand to accuse someone of a crime,
speaker: Narrator

text: the two people involved in the dispute must stand in the presence of the Lord before the priests and the judges who are in office at the time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The judges must make a thorough investigation, and if the witness proves to be a liar, giving false testimony against a fellow Israelite,
speaker: Narrator

text: then do to the false witness as that witness intended to do to the other party. You must purge the evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the people will hear of this and be afraid, and never again will such an evil thing be done among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Show no pity: life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you go to war against your enemies and see horses and chariots and an army greater than yours, do not be afraid of them, because the Lord your God, who brought you up out of Egypt, will be with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you are about to go into battle, the priest shall come forward and address the army.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall say: ‘Hear, Israel: today you are going into battle against your enemies. Do not be faint-hearted or afraid; do not panic or be terrified by them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God is the one who goes with you to fight for you against your enemies to give you victory.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The officers shall say to the army: ‘Has anyone built a new house and not yet begun to live in it? Let him go home, or he may die in battle and someone else may begin to live in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Has anyone planted a vineyard and not begun to enjoy it? Let him go home, or he may die in battle and someone else enjoy it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Has anyone become pledged to a woman and not married her? Let him go home, or he may die in battle and someone else marry her.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the officers shall add, ‘Is anyone afraid or faint-hearted? Let him go home so that his fellow soldiers will not become disheartened too.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When the officers have finished speaking to the army, they shall appoint commanders over it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you march up to attack a city, make its people an offer of peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they accept and open their gates, all the people in it shall be subject to forced labour and shall work for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they refuse to make peace and they engage you in battle, lay siege to that city.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God delivers it into your hand, put to the sword all the men in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the women, the children, the livestock and everything else in the city, you may take these as plunder for yourselves. And you may use the plunder the Lord your God gives you from your enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how you are to treat all the cities that are at a distance from you and do not belong to the nations nearby.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, in the cities of the nations the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance, do not leave alive anything that breathes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Completely destroy them – the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites – as the Lord your God has commanded you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, they will teach you to follow all the detestable things they do in worshipping their gods, and you will sin against the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you lay siege to a city for a long time, fighting against it to capture it, do not destroy its trees by putting an axe to them, because you can eat their fruit. Do not cut them down. Are the trees people, that you should besiege them?
speaker: Narrator

text: However, you may cut down trees that you know are not fruit trees and use them to build siege works until the city at war with you falls.
speaker: Narrator

text: If someone is found slain, lying in a field in the land the Lord your God is giving you to possess, and it is not known who the killer was,
speaker: Narrator

text: your elders and judges shall go out and measure the distance from the body to the neighbouring towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the elders of the town nearest the body shall take a heifer that has never been worked and has never worn a yoke
speaker: Narrator

text: and lead it down to a valley that has not been ploughed or planted and where there is a flowing stream. There in the valley they are to break the heifer’s neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levitical priests shall step forward, for the Lord your God has chosen them to minister and to pronounce blessings in the name of the Lord and to decide all cases of dispute and assault.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the elders of the town nearest the body shall wash their hands over the heifer whose neck was broken in the valley,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they shall declare: ‘Our hands did not shed this blood, nor did our eyes see it done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Accept this atonement for your people Israel, whom you have redeemed, Lord, and do not hold your people guilty of the blood of an innocent person.’ Then the bloodshed will be atoned for,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you will have purged from yourselves the guilt of shedding innocent blood, since you have done what is right in the eyes of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you go to war against your enemies and the Lord your God delivers them into your hands and you take captives,
speaker: Narrator

text: if you notice among the captives a beautiful woman and are attracted to her, you may take her as your wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring her into your home and make her shave her head, trim her nails
speaker: Narrator

text: and put aside the clothes she was wearing when captured. After she has lived in your house and mourned her father and mother for a full month, then you may go to her and be her husband and she shall be your wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you are not pleased with her, let her go wherever she wishes. You must not sell her or treat her as a slave, since you have dishonoured her.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man has two wives, and he loves one but not the other, and both bear him sons but the firstborn is the son of the wife he does not love,
speaker: Narrator

text: when he wills his property to his sons, he must not give the rights of the firstborn to the son of the wife he loves in preference to his actual firstborn, the son of the wife he does not love.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must acknowledge the son of his unloved wife as the firstborn by giving him a double share of all he has. That son is the first sign of his father’s strength. The right of the firstborn belongs to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If someone has a stubborn and rebellious son who does not obey his father and mother and will not listen to them when they discipline him,
speaker: Narrator

text: his father and mother shall take hold of him and bring him to the elders at the gate of his town.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall say to the elders, ‘This son of ours is stubborn and rebellious. He will not obey us. He is a glutton and a drunkard.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the men of his town are to stone him to death. You must purge the evil from among you. All Israel will hear of it and be afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: If someone guilty of a capital offence is put to death and their body is exposed on a pole,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must not leave the body hanging on the pole overnight. Be sure to bury it that same day, because anyone who is hung on a pole is under God’s curse. You must not desecrate the land the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you see your fellow Israelite’s ox or sheep straying, do not ignore it but be sure to take it back to its owner.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they do not live near you or if you do not know who owns it, take it home with you and keep it until they come looking for it. Then give it back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do the same if you find their donkey or cloak or anything else they have lost. Do not ignore it.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you see your fellow Israelite’s donkey or ox fallen on the road, do not ignore it. Help the owner to get it to its feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: A woman must not wear men’s clothing, nor a man wear women’s clothing, for the Lord your God detests anyone who does this.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you come across a bird’s nest beside the road, either in a tree or on the ground, and the mother is sitting on the young or on the eggs, do not take the mother with the young.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may take the young, but be sure to let the mother go, so that it may go well with you and you may have a long life.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you build a new house, make a parapet around your roof so that you may not bring the guilt of bloodshed on your house if someone falls from the roof.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not plant two kinds of seed in your vineyard; if you do, not only the crops you plant but also the fruit of the vineyard will be defiled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not plough with an ox and a donkey yoked together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not wear clothes of wool and linen woven together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make tassels on the four corners of the cloak you wear.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man takes a wife and, after sleeping with her, dislikes her
speaker: Narrator

text: and slanders her and gives her a bad name, saying, ‘I married this woman, but when I approached her, I did not find proof of her virginity,’
speaker: Narrator

text: then the young woman’s father and mother shall bring to the town elders at the gate proof that she was a virgin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her father will say to the elders, ‘I gave my daughter in marriage to this man, but he dislikes her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now he has slandered her and said, “I did not find your daughter to be a virgin.” But here is the proof of my daughter’s virginity.’ Then her parents shall display the cloth before the elders of the town,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the elders shall take the man and punish him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall fine him a hundred shekels of silver and give them to the young woman’s father, because this man has given an Israelite virgin a bad name. She shall continue to be his wife; he must not divorce her as long as he lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, the charge is true and no proof of the young woman’s virginity can be found,
speaker: Narrator

text: she shall be brought to the door of her father’s house and there the men of her town shall stone her to death. She has done an outrageous thing in Israel by being promiscuous while still in her father’s house. You must purge the evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man is found sleeping with another man’s wife, both the man who slept with her and the woman must die. You must purge the evil from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man happens to meet in a town a virgin pledged to be married and he sleeps with her,
speaker: Narrator

text: you shall take both of them to the gate of that town and stone them to death – the young woman because she was in a town and did not scream for help, and the man because he violated another man’s wife. You must purge the evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if out in the country a man happens to meet a young woman pledged to be married and rapes her, only the man who has done this shall die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do nothing to the woman; she has committed no sin deserving death. This case is like that of someone who attacks and murders a neighbour,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the man found the young woman out in the country, and though the betrothed woman screamed, there was no one to rescue her.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man happens to meet a virgin who is not pledged to be married and rapes her and they are discovered,
speaker: Narrator

text: he shall pay her father fifty shekels of silver. He must marry the young woman, for he has violated her. He can never divorce her as long as he lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man is not to marry his father’s wife; he must not dishonour his father’s bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one who has been emasculated by crushing or cutting may enter the assembly of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one born of a forbidden marriage nor any of their descendants may enter the assembly of the Lord, not even in the tenth generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: No Ammonite or Moabite or any of their descendants may enter the assembly of the Lord, not even in the tenth generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they did not come to meet you with bread and water on your way when you came out of Egypt, and they hired Balaam son of Beor from Pethor in Aram Naharaim to pronounce a curse on you.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the Lord your God would not listen to Balaam but turned the curse into a blessing for you, because the Lord your God loves you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not seek a treaty of friendship with them as long as you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not despise an Edomite, for the Edomites are related to you. Do not despise an Egyptian, because you resided as foreigners in their country.
speaker: Narrator

text: The third generation of children born to them may enter the assembly of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you set up camp against your enemies, keep away from everything impure.
speaker: Narrator

text: If one of your men is unclean because of a nocturnal emission, he is to go outside the camp and stay there.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as evening approaches he is to wash himself, and at sunset he may return to the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Designate a place outside the camp where you can go to relieve yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: As part of your equipment have something to dig with, and when you relieve yourself, dig a hole and cover up your excrement.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God moves about in your camp to protect you and to deliver your enemies to you. Your camp must be holy, so that he will not see among you anything indecent and turn away from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a slave has taken refuge with you, do not hand them over to their master.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them live among you wherever they like and in whatever town they choose. Do not oppress them.
speaker: Narrator

text: No Israelite man or woman is to become a shrine-prostitute.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not bring the earnings of a female prostitute or of a male prostitute into the house of the Lord your God to pay any vow, because the Lord your God detests them both.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not charge a fellow Israelite interest, whether on money or food or anything else that may earn interest.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may charge a foreigner interest, but not a fellow Israelite, so that the Lord your God may bless you in everything you put your hand to in the land you are entering to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you make a vow to the Lord your God, do not be slow to pay it, for the Lord your God will certainly demand it of you and you will be guilty of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you refrain from making a vow, you will not be guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever your lips utter you must be sure to do, because you made your vow freely to the Lord your God with your own mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you enter your neighbour’s vineyard, you may eat all the grapes you want, but do not put any in your basket.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you enter your neighbour’s cornfield, you may pick the ears with your hands, but you must not put a sickle to their standing corn.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man marries a woman who becomes displeasing to him because he finds something indecent about her, and he writes her a certificate of divorce, gives it to her and sends her from his house,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if after she leaves his house she becomes the wife of another man,
speaker: Narrator

text: and her second husband dislikes her and writes her a certificate of divorce, gives it to her and sends her from his house, or if he dies,
speaker: Narrator

text: then her first husband, who divorced her, is not allowed to marry her again after she has been defiled. That would be detestable in the eyes of the Lord. Do not bring sin upon the land the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man has recently married, he must not be sent to war or have any other duty laid on him. For one year he is to be free to stay at home and bring happiness to the wife he has married.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not take a pair of millstones – not even the upper one – as security for a debt, because that would be taking a person’s livelihood as security.
speaker: Narrator

text: If someone is caught kidnapping a fellow Israelite and treating or selling them as a slave, the kidnapper must die. You must purge the evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: In cases of defiling skin diseases, be very careful to do exactly as the Levitical priests instruct you. You must follow carefully what I have commanded them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember what the Lord your God did to Miriam along the way after you came out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you make a loan of any kind to your neighbour, do not go into their house to get what is offered to you as a pledge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stay outside and let the neighbour to whom you are making the loan bring the pledge out to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the neighbour is poor, do not go to sleep with their pledge in your possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: Return their cloak by sunset so that your neighbour may sleep in it. Then they will thank you, and it will be regarded as a righteous act in the sight of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not take advantage of a hired worker who is poor and needy, whether that worker is a fellow Israelite or a foreigner residing in one of your towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pay them their wages each day before sunset, because they are poor and are counting on it. Otherwise they may cry to the Lord against you, and you will be guilty of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Parents are not to be put to death for their children, nor children put to death for their parents; each will die for their own sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not deprive the foreigner or the fatherless of justice, or take the cloak of the widow as a pledge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that you were slaves in Egypt and the Lord your God redeemed you from there. That is why I command you to do this.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you are harvesting in your field and you overlook a sheaf, do not go back to get it. Leave it for the foreigner, the fatherless and the widow, so that the Lord your God may bless you in all the work of your hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you beat the olives from your trees, do not go over the branches a second time. Leave what remains for the foreigner, the fatherless and the widow.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you harvest the grapes in your vineyard, do not go over the vines again. Leave what remains for the foreigner, the fatherless and the widow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that you were slaves in Egypt. That is why I command you to do this.
speaker: Narrator

text: When people have a dispute, they are to take it to court and the judges will decide the case, acquitting the innocent and condemning the guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the guilty person deserves to be beaten, the judge shall make them lie down and have them flogged in his presence with the number of lashes the crime deserves,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the judge must not impose more than forty lashes. If the guilty party is flogged more than that, your fellow Israelite will be degraded in your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not muzzle an ox while it is treading out the grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: If brothers are living together and one of them dies without a son, his widow must not marry outside the family. Her husband’s brother shall take her and marry her and fulfil the duty of a brother-in-law to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first son she bears shall carry on the name of the dead brother so that his name will not be blotted out from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if a man does not want to marry his brother’s wife, she shall go to the elders at the town gate and say, ‘My husband’s brother refuses to carry on his brother’s name in Israel. He will not fulfil the duty of a brother-in-law to me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the elders of his town shall summon him and talk to him. If he persists in saying, ‘I do not want to marry her,’
speaker: Narrator

text: his brother’s widow shall go up to him in the presence of the elders, take off one of his sandals, spit in his face and say, ‘This is what is done to the man who will not build up his brother’s family line.’
speaker: Narrator

text: That man’s line shall be known in Israel as The Family of the Unsandalled.
speaker: Narrator

text: If two men are fighting and the wife of one of them comes to rescue her husband from his assailant, and she reaches out and seizes him by his private parts,
speaker: Narrator

text: you shall cut off her hand. Show her no pity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not have two differing weights in your bag – one heavy, one light.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not have two differing measures in your house – one large, one small.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must have accurate and honest weights and measures, so that you may live long in the land the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God detests anyone who does these things, anyone who deals dishonestly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember what the Amalekites did to you along the way when you came out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you were weary and worn out, they met you on your journey and attacked all who were lagging behind; they had no fear of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God gives you rest from all the enemies around you in the land he is giving you to possess as an inheritance, you shall blot out the name of Amalek from under heaven. Do not forget!
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have entered the land that the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance and have taken possession of it and settled in it,
speaker: Narrator

text: take some of the firstfruits of all that you produce from the soil of the land that the Lord your God is giving you and put them in a basket. Then go to the place that the Lord your God will choose as a dwelling for his Name
speaker: Narrator

text: and say to the priest in office at the time, ‘I declare today to the Lord your God that I have come to the land the Lord swore to our ancestors to give us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest shall take the basket from your hands and set it down in front of the altar of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you shall declare before the Lord your God: ‘My father was a wandering Aramean, and he went down into Egypt with a few people and lived there and became a great nation, powerful and numerous.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Egyptians ill-treated us and made us suffer, subjecting us to harsh labour.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then we cried out to the Lord, the God of our ancestors, and the Lord heard our voice and saw our misery, toil and oppression.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord brought us out of Egypt with a mighty hand and an outstretched arm, with great terror and with signs and wonders.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought us to this place and gave us this land, a land flowing with milk and honey;
speaker: Narrator

text: and now I bring the firstfruits of the soil that you, Lord, have given me.’ Place the basket before the Lord your God and bow down before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you and the Levites and the foreigners residing among you shall rejoice in all the good things the Lord your God has given to you and your household.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have finished setting aside a tenth of all your produce in the third year, the year of the tithe, you shall give it to the Levite, the foreigner, the fatherless and the widow, so that they may eat in your towns and be satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then say to the Lord your God: ‘I have removed from my house the sacred portion and have given it to the Levite, the foreigner, the fatherless and the widow, according to all you commanded. I have not turned aside from your commands nor have I forgotten any of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have not eaten any of the sacred portion while I was in mourning, nor have I removed any of it while I was unclean, nor have I offered any of it to the dead. I have obeyed the Lord my God; I have done everything you commanded me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look down from heaven, your holy dwelling-place, and bless your people Israel and the land you have given us as you promised on oath to our ancestors, a land flowing with milk and honey.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God commands you this day to follow these decrees and laws; carefully observe them with all your heart and with all your soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have declared this day that the Lord is your God and that you will walk in obedience to him, that you will keep his decrees, commands and laws – that you will listen to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord has declared this day that you are his people, his treasured possession as he promised, and that you are to keep all his commands.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has declared that he will set you in praise, fame and honour high above all the nations he has made and that you will be a people holy to the Lord your God, as he promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and the elders of Israel commanded the people: ‘Keep all these commands that I give you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have crossed the Jordan into the land the Lord your God is giving you, set up some large stones and coat them with plaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: Write on them all the words of this law when you have crossed over to enter the land the Lord your God is giving you, a land flowing with milk and honey, just as the Lord, the God of your ancestors, promised you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when you have crossed the Jordan, set up these stones on Mount Ebal, as I command you today, and coat them with plaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: Build there an altar to the Lord your God, an altar of stones. Do not use any iron tool on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Build the altar of the Lord your God with stones from the field and offer burnt offerings on it to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sacrifice fellowship offerings there, eating them and rejoicing in the presence of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you shall write very clearly all the words of this law on these stones you have set up.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and the Levitical priests said to all Israel, ‘Be silent, Israel, and listen! You have now become the people of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Obey the Lord your God and follow his commands and decrees that I give you today.’
speaker: Narrator

text: On the same day Moses commanded the people:
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have crossed the Jordan, these tribes shall stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: And these tribes shall stand on Mount Ebal to pronounce curses: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan and Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites shall recite to all the people of Israel in a loud voice:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who makes an idol – a thing detestable to the Lord, the work of skilled hands – and sets it up in secret.’
Then all the people shall say, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who dishonours their father or mother.’
Then all the people shall say, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who moves their neighbour’s boundary stone.’
Then all the people shall say, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who leads the blind astray on the road.’
Then all the people shall say, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who withholds justice from the foreigner, the fatherless or the widow.’
Then all the people shall say, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who sleeps with his father’s wife, for he dishonours his father’s bed.’
Then all the people shall say, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who has sexual relations with any animal.’
Then all the people shall say, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who sleeps with his sister, the daughter of his father or the daughter of his mother.’
Then all the people shall say, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who sleeps with his mother-in-law.’
Then all the people shall say, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who kills their neighbour secretly.’
Then all the people shall say, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who accepts a bribe to kill an innocent person.’
Then all the people shall say, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who does not uphold the words of this law by carrying them out.’
Then all the people shall say, ‘Amen!’
speaker: Narrator

text: If you fully obey the Lord your God and carefully follow all his commands that I give you today, the Lord your God will set you high above all the nations on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these blessings will come on you and accompany you if you obey the Lord your God:
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be blessed in the city and blessed in the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fruit of your womb will be blessed, and the crops of your land and the young of your livestock – the calves of your herds and the lambs of your flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your basket and your kneading trough will be blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be blessed when you come in and blessed when you go out.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will grant that the enemies who rise up against you will be defeated before you. They will come at you from one direction but flee from you in seven.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will send a blessing on your barns and on everything you put your hand to. The Lord your God will bless you in the land he is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will establish you as his holy people, as he promised you on oath, if you keep the commands of the Lord your God and walk in obedience to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the peoples on earth will see that you are called by the name of the Lord, and they will fear you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will grant you abundant prosperity – in the fruit of your womb, the young of your livestock and the crops of your ground – in the land he swore to your ancestors to give you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will open the heavens, the storehouse of his bounty, to send rain on your land in season and to bless all the work of your hands. You will lend to many nations but will borrow from none.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will make you the head, not the tail. If you pay attention to the commands of the Lord your God that I give you this day and carefully follow them, you will always be at the top, never at the bottom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not turn aside from any of the commands I give you today, to the right or to the left, following other gods and serving them.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if you do not obey the Lord your God and do not carefully follow all his commands and decrees I am giving you today, all these curses will come on you and overtake you:
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be cursed in the city and cursed in the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your basket and your kneading trough will be cursed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fruit of your womb will be cursed, and the crops of your land, and the calves of your herds and the lambs of your flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be cursed when you come in and cursed when you go out.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will send on you curses, confusion and rebuke in everything you put your hand to, until you are destroyed and come to sudden ruin because of the evil you have done in forsaking him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will plague you with diseases until he has destroyed you from the land you are entering to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will strike you with wasting disease, with fever and inflammation, with scorching heat and drought, with blight and mildew, which will plague you until you perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sky over your head will be bronze, the ground beneath you iron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will turn the rain of your country into dust and powder; it will come down from the skies until you are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will cause you to be defeated before your enemies. You will come at them from one direction but flee from them in seven, and you will become a thing of horror to all the kingdoms on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your carcasses will be food for all the birds and the wild animals, and there will be no one to frighten them away.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will afflict you with the boils of Egypt and with tumours, festering sores and the itch, from which you cannot be cured.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will afflict you with madness, blindness and confusion of mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: At midday you will grope about like a blind person in the dark. You will be unsuccessful in everything you do; day after day you will be oppressed and robbed, with no one to rescue you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be pledged to be married to a woman, but another will take her and rape her. You will build a house, but you will not live in it. You will plant a vineyard, but you will not even begin to enjoy its fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your ox will be slaughtered before your eyes, but you will eat none of it. Your donkey will be forcibly taken from you and will not be returned. Your sheep will be given to your enemies, and no one will rescue them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your sons and daughters will be given to another nation, and you will wear out your eyes watching for them day after day, powerless to lift a hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: A people that you do not know will eat what your land and labour produce, and you will have nothing but cruel oppression all your days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sights you see will drive you mad.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will afflict your knees and legs with painful boils that cannot be cured, spreading from the soles of your feet to the top of your head.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will drive you and the king you set over you to a nation unknown to you or your ancestors. There you will worship other gods, gods of wood and stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will become a thing of horror, a byword and an object of ridicule among all the peoples where the Lord will drive you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will sow much seed in the field but you will harvest little, because locusts will devour it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will plant vineyards and cultivate them but you will not drink the wine or gather the grapes, because worms will eat them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will have olive trees throughout your country but you will not use the oil, because the olives will drop off.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will have sons and daughters but you will not keep them, because they will go into captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Swarms of locusts will take over all your trees and the crops of your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The foreigners who reside among you will rise above you higher and higher, but you will sink lower and lower.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will lend to you, but you will not lend to them. They will be the head, but you will be the tail.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these curses will come on you. They will pursue you and overtake you until you are destroyed, because you did not obey the Lord your God and observe the commands and decrees he gave you.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will be a sign and a wonder to you and your descendants for ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you did not serve the Lord your God joyfully and gladly in the time of prosperity,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore in hunger and thirst, in nakedness and dire poverty, you will serve the enemies the Lord sends against you. He will put an iron yoke on your neck until he has destroyed you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will bring a nation against you from far away, from the ends of the earth, like an eagle swooping down, a nation whose language you will not understand,
speaker: Narrator

text: a fierce-looking nation without respect for the old or pity for the young.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will devour the young of your livestock and the crops of your land until you are destroyed. They will leave you no corn, new wine or olive oil, nor any calves of your herds or lambs of your flocks until you are ruined.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will lay siege to all the cities throughout your land until the high fortified walls in which you trust fall down. They will besiege all the cities throughout the land the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of the suffering your enemy will inflict on you during the siege, you will eat the fruit of the womb, the flesh of the sons and daughters the Lord your God has given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even the most gentle and sensitive man among you will have no compassion on his own brother or the wife he loves or his surviving children,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he will not give to one of them any of the flesh of his children that he is eating. It will be all he has left because of the suffering that your enemy will inflict on you during the siege of all your cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: The most gentle and sensitive woman among you – so sensitive and gentle that she would not venture to touch the ground with the sole of her foot – will begrudge the husband she loves and her own son or daughter
speaker: Narrator

text: the afterbirth from her womb and the children she bears. For in her dire need she intends to eat them secretly because of the suffering your enemy will inflict on you during the siege of your cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do not carefully follow all the words of this law, which are written in this book, and do not revere this glorious and awesome name – the Lord your God –
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord will send fearful plagues on you and your descendants, harsh and prolonged disasters, and severe and lingering illnesses.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will bring on you all the diseases of Egypt that you dreaded, and they will cling to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will also bring on you every kind of sickness and disaster not recorded in this Book of the Law, until you are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: You who were as numerous as the stars in the sky will be left but few in number, because you did not obey the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as it pleased the Lord to make you prosper and increase in number, so it will please him to ruin and destroy you. You will be uprooted from the land you are entering to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord will scatter you among all nations, from one end of the earth to the other. There you will worship other gods – gods of wood and stone, which neither you nor your ancestors have known.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among those nations you will find no repose, no resting place for the sole of your foot. There the Lord will give you an anxious mind, eyes weary with longing, and a despairing heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will live in constant suspense, filled with dread both night and day, never sure of your life.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning you will say, ‘If only it were evening!’ and in the evening, ‘If only it were morning!’– because of the terror that will fill your hearts and the sights that your eyes will see.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will send you back in ships to Egypt on a journey I said you should never make again. There you will offer yourselves for sale to your enemies as male and female slaves, but no one will buy you.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the terms of the covenant the Lord commanded Moses to make with the Israelites in Moab, in addition to the covenant he had made with them at Horeb.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses summoned all the Israelites and said to them:
Your eyes have seen all that the Lord did in Egypt to Pharaoh, to all his officials and to all his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: With your own eyes you saw those great trials, those signs and great wonders.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to this day the Lord has not given you a mind that understands or eyes that see or ears that hear.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the Lord says, ‘During the forty years that I led you through the wilderness, your clothes did not wear out, nor did the sandals on your feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: You ate no bread and drank no wine or other fermented drink. I did this so that you might know that I am the Lord your God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When you reached this place, Sihon king of Heshbon and Og king of Bashan came out to fight against us, but we defeated them.
speaker: Narrator

text: We took their land and gave it as an inheritance to the Reubenites, the Gadites and the half-tribe of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Carefully follow the terms of this covenant, so that you may prosper in everything you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of you are standing today in the presence of the Lord your God – your leaders and chief men, your elders and officials, and all the other men of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: together with your children and your wives, and the foreigners living in your camps who chop your wood and carry your water.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are standing here in order to enter into a covenant with the Lord your God, a covenant the Lord is making with you this day and sealing with an oath,
speaker: Narrator

text: to confirm you this day as his people, that he may be your God as he promised you and as he swore to your fathers, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am making this covenant, with its oath, not only with you
speaker: Narrator

text: who are standing here with us today in the presence of the Lord our God but also with those who are not here today.
speaker: Narrator

text: You yourselves know how we lived in Egypt and how we passed through the countries on the way here.
speaker: Narrator

text: You saw among them their detestable images and idols of wood and stone, of silver and gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make sure there is no man or woman, clan or tribe among you today whose heart turns away from the Lord our God to go and worship the gods of those nations; make sure there is no root among you that produces such bitter poison.
speaker: Narrator

text: When such a person hears the words of this oath and they invoke a blessing on themselves, thinking, ‘I will be safe, even though I persist in going my own way,’ they will bring disaster on the watered land as well as the dry.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will never be willing to forgive them; his wrath and zeal will burn against them. All the curses written in this book will fall on them, and the Lord will blot out their names from under heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will single them out from all the tribes of Israel for disaster, according to all the curses of the covenant written in this Book of the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your children who follow you in later generations and foreigners who come from distant lands will see the calamities that have fallen on the land and the diseases with which the Lord has afflicted it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole land will be a burning waste of salt and sulphur – nothing planted, nothing sprouting, no vegetation growing on it. It will be like the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah, Admah and Zeboyim, which the Lord overthrew in fierce anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the nations will ask: ‘Why has the Lord done this to this land? Why this fierce, burning anger?’
speaker: Narrator

text: And the answer will be: ‘It is because this people abandoned the covenant of the Lord, the God of their ancestors, the covenant he made with them when he brought them out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went off and worshipped other gods and bowed down to them, gods they did not know, gods he had not given them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord’s anger burned against this land, so that he brought on it all the curses written in this book.
speaker: Narrator

text: In furious anger and in great wrath the Lord uprooted them from their land and thrust them into another land, as it is now.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The secret things belong to the Lord our God, but the things revealed belong to us and to our children for ever, that we may follow all the words of this law.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all these blessings and curses I have set before you come on you and you take them to heart wherever the Lord your God disperses you among the nations,
speaker: Narrator

text: and when you and your children return to the Lord your God and obey him with all your heart and with all your soul according to everything I command you today,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the Lord your God will restore your fortunes and have compassion on you and gather you again from all the nations where he scattered you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if you have been banished to the most distant land under the heavens, from there the Lord your God will gather you and bring you back.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will bring you to the land that belonged to your ancestors, and you will take possession of it. He will make you more prosperous and numerous than your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will circumcise your hearts and the hearts of your descendants, so that you may love him with all your heart and with all your soul, and live.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will put all these curses on your enemies who hate and persecute you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will again obey the Lord and follow all his commands I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord your God will make you most prosperous in all the work of your hands and in the fruit of your womb, the young of your livestock and the crops of your land. The Lord will again delight in you and make you prosperous, just as he delighted in your ancestors,
speaker: Narrator

text: if you obey the Lord your God and keep his commands and decrees that are written in this Book of the Law and turn to the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now what I am commanding you today is not too difficult for you or beyond your reach.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not up in heaven, so that you have to ask, ‘Who will ascend into heaven to get it and proclaim it to us so that we may obey it?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Nor is it beyond the sea, so that you have to ask, ‘Who will cross the sea to get it and proclaim it to us so that we may obey it?’
speaker: Narrator

text: No, the word is very near you; it is in your mouth and in your heart so that you may obey it.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I set before you today life and prosperity, death and destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I command you today to love the Lord your God, to walk in obedience to him, and to keep his commands, decrees and laws; then you will live and increase, and the Lord your God will bless you in the land you are entering to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if your heart turns away and you are not obedient, and if you are drawn away to bow down to other gods and worship them,
speaker: Narrator

text: I declare to you this day that you will certainly be destroyed. You will not live long in the land you are crossing the Jordan to enter and possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: This day I call the heavens and the earth as witnesses against you that I have set before you life and death, blessings and curses. Now choose life, so that you and your children may live
speaker: Narrator

text: and that you may love the Lord your God, listen to his voice, and hold fast to him. For the Lord is your life, and he will give you many years in the land he swore to give to your fathers, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses went out and spoke these words to all Israel:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I am now a hundred and twenty years old and I am no longer able to lead you. The Lord has said to me, “You shall not cross the Jordan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God himself will cross over ahead of you. He will destroy these nations before you, and you will take possession of their land. Joshua also will cross over ahead of you, as the Lord said.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord will do to them what he did to Sihon and Og, the kings of the Amorites, whom he destroyed along with their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will deliver them to you, and you must do to them all that I have commanded you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be strong and courageous. Do not be afraid or terrified because of them, for the Lord your God goes with you; he will never leave you nor forsake you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses summoned Joshua and said to him in the presence of all Israel, ‘Be strong and courageous, for you must go with this people into the land that the Lord swore to their ancestors to give them, and you must divide it among them as their inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord himself goes before you and will be with you; he will never leave you nor forsake you. Do not be afraid; do not be discouraged.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses wrote down this law and gave it to the Levitical priests, who carried the ark of the covenant of the Lord, and to all the elders of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses commanded them: ‘At the end of every seven years, in the year for cancelling debts, during the Festival of Tabernacles,
speaker: Narrator

text: when all Israel comes to appear before the Lord your God at the place he will choose, you shall read this law before them in their hearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Assemble the people – men, women and children, and the foreigners residing in your towns – so that they can listen and learn to fear the Lord your God and follow carefully all the words of this law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their children, who do not know this law, must hear it and learn to fear the Lord your God as long as you live in the land you are crossing the Jordan to possess.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, ‘Now the day of your death is near. Call Joshua and present yourselves at the tent of meeting, where I will commission him.’ So Moses and Joshua came and presented themselves at the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord appeared at the tent in a pillar of cloud, and the cloud stood over the entrance to the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to Moses: ‘You are going to rest with your ancestors, and these people will soon prostitute themselves to the foreign gods of the land they are entering. They will forsake me and break the covenant I made with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in that day I will become angry with them and forsake them; I will hide my face from them, and they will be destroyed. Many disasters and calamities will come on them, and in that day they will ask, “Have not these disasters come on us because our God is not with us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will certainly hide my face in that day because of all their wickedness in turning to other gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Now write down this song and teach it to the Israelites and make them sing it, so that it may be a witness for me against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I have brought them into the land flowing with milk and honey, the land I promised on oath to their ancestors, and when they eat their fill and thrive, they will turn to other gods and worship them, rejecting me and breaking my covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when many disasters and calamities come on them, this song will testify against them, because it will not be forgotten by their descendants. I know what they are disposed to do, even before I bring them into the land I promised them on oath.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses wrote down this song that day and taught it to the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord gave this command to Joshua son of Nun: ‘Be strong and courageous, for you will bring the Israelites into the land I promised them on oath, and I myself will be with you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: After Moses finished writing in a book the words of this law from beginning to end,
speaker: Narrator

text: he gave this command to the Levites who carried the ark of the covenant of the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Take this Book of the Law and place it beside the ark of the covenant of the Lord your God. There it will remain as a witness against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I know how rebellious and stiff-necked you are. If you have been rebellious against the Lord while I am still alive and with you, how much more will you rebel after I die!
speaker: Narrator

text: Assemble before me all the elders of your tribes and all your officials, so that I can speak these words in their hearing and call the heavens and the earth to testify against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I know that after my death you are sure to become utterly corrupt and to turn from the way I have commanded you. In days to come, disaster will fall on you because you will do evil in the sight of the Lord and arouse his anger by what your hands have made.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses recited the words of this song from beginning to end in the hearing of the whole assembly of Israel:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen, you heavens, and I will speak;
    hear, you earth, the words of my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let my teaching fall like rain
    and my words descend like dew,
like showers on new grass,
    like abundant rain on tender plants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will proclaim the name of the Lord.
    Oh, praise the greatness of our God!
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is the Rock, his works are perfect,
    and all his ways are just.
A faithful God who does no wrong,
    upright and just is he.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are corrupt and not his children;
    to their shame they are a warped and crooked generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is this the way you repay the Lord,
    you foolish and unwise people?
Is he not your Father, your Creator,
    who made you and formed you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember the days of old;
    consider the generations long past.
Ask your father and he will tell you,
    your elders, and they will explain to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Most High gave the nations their inheritance,
    when he divided all mankind,
he set up boundaries for the peoples
    according to the number of the sons of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord’s portion is his people,
    Jacob his allotted inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In a desert land he found him,
    in a barren and howling waste.
He shielded him and cared for him;
    he guarded him as the apple of his eye,
speaker: Narrator

text:
like an eagle that stirs up its nest
    and hovers over its young,
that spreads its wings to catch them
    and carries them on its pinions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord alone led him;
    no foreign god was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made him ride on the heights of the land
    and fed him with the fruit of the fields.
He nourished him with honey from the rock,
    and with oil from the flinty crag,
speaker: Narrator

text:
with curds and milk from herd and flock
    and with fattened lambs and goats,
with choice rams of Bashan
    and the finest grains of wheat.
You drank the foaming blood of the grape.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jeshurun grew fat and kicked;
    filled with food, they became heavy and sleek.
They abandoned the God who made them
    and rejected the Rock their Saviour.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They made him jealous with their foreign gods
    and angered him with their detestable idols.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They sacrificed to false gods, which are not God –
    gods they had not known,
    gods that recently appeared,
    gods your ancestors did not fear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You deserted the Rock, who fathered you;
    you forgot the God who gave you birth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord saw this and rejected them
    because he was angered by his sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They made me jealous by what is no god
    and angered me with their worthless idols.
I will make them envious by those who are not a people;
    I will make them angry by a nation that has no understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For a fire will be kindled by my wrath,
    one that burns down to the realm of the dead below.
It will devour the earth and its harvests
    and set on fire the foundations of the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘I will heap calamities on them
    and expend my arrows against them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will send wasting famine against them,
    consuming pestilence and deadly plague;
I will send against them the fangs of wild beasts,
    the venom of vipers that glide in the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the street the sword will make them childless;
    in their homes terror will reign.
The young men and young women will perish,
    the infants and those with grey hair.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said I would scatter them
    and erase their name from human memory,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but I dreaded the taunt of the enemy,
    lest the adversary misunderstand
and say, “Our hand has triumphed;
    the Lord has not done all this.”’
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are a nation without sense,
    there is no discernment in them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If only they were wise and would understand this
    and discern what their end will be!
speaker: Narrator

text:
How could one man chase a thousand,
    or two put ten thousand to flight,
unless their Rock had sold them,
    unless the Lord had given them up?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For their rock is not like our Rock,
    as even our enemies concede.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their vine comes from the vine of Sodom
    and from the fields of Gomorrah.
Their grapes are filled with poison,
    and their clusters with bitterness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their wine is the venom of serpents,
    the deadly poison of cobras.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Have I not kept this in reserve
    and sealed it in my vaults?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is mine to avenge; I will repay.
    In due time their foot will slip;
their day of disaster is near
    and their doom rushes upon them.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will vindicate his people
    and relent concerning his servants
when he sees their strength is gone
    and no one is left, slave or free.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will say: ‘Now where are their gods,
    the rock they took refuge in,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the gods who ate the fat of their sacrifices
    and drank the wine of their drink offerings?
Let them rise up to help you!
    Let them give you shelter!
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘See now that I myself am he!
    There is no god besides me.
I put to death and I bring to life,
    I have wounded and I will heal,
    and no one can deliver out of my hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I lift my hand to heaven and solemnly swear:
    as surely as I live for ever,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when I sharpen my flashing sword
    and my hand grasps it in judgment,
I will take vengeance on my adversaries
    and repay those who hate me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will make my arrows drunk with blood,
    while my sword devours flesh:
the blood of the slain and the captives,
    the heads of the enemy leaders.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rejoice, you nations, with his people,
    for he will avenge the blood of his servants;
he will take vengeance on his enemies
    and make atonement for his land and people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses came with Joshua son of Nun and spoke all the words of this song in the hearing of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses had finished reciting all these words to all Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: he said to them, ‘Take to heart all the words I have solemnly declared to you this day, so that you may command your children to obey carefully all the words of this law.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are not just idle words for you – they are your life. By them you will live long in the land you are crossing the Jordan to possess.’
speaker: Narrator

text: On that same day the Lord told Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Go up into the Abarim Range to Mount Nebo in Moab, opposite Jericho, and view Canaan, the land I am giving the Israelites as their own possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: There on the mountain that you have climbed you will die and be gathered to your people, just as your brother Aaron died on Mount Hor and was gathered to his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is because both of you broke faith with me in the presence of the Israelites at the waters of Meribah Kadesh in the Desert of Zin and because you did not uphold my holiness among the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, you will see the land only from a distance; you will not enter the land I am giving to the people of Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the blessing that Moses the man of God pronounced on the Israelites before his death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said:
‘The Lord came from Sinai
    and dawned over them from Seir;
    he shone forth from Mount Paran.
He came with myriads of holy ones
    from the south, from his mountain slopes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely it is you who love the people;
    all the holy ones are in your hand.
At your feet they all bow down,
    and from you receive instruction,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the law that Moses gave us,
    the possession of the assembly of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He was king over Jeshurun
    when the leaders of the people assembled,
    along with the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Let Reuben live and not die,
    nor his people be few.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
And this he said about Judah:
‘Hear, Lord, the cry of Judah;
    bring him to his people.
With his own hands he defends his cause.
    Oh, be his help against his foes!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
About Levi he said:
‘Your Thummim and Urim belong
    to your faithful servant.
You tested him at Massah;
    you contended with him at the waters of Meribah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said of his father and mother,
    “I have no regard for them.”
He did not recognise his brothers
    or acknowledge his own children,
but he watched over your word
    and guarded your covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He teaches your precepts to Jacob
    and your law to Israel.
He offers incense before you
    and whole burnt offerings on your altar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bless all his skills, Lord,
    and be pleased with the work of his hands.
Strike down those who rise against him,
    his foes till they rise no more.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
About Benjamin he said:
‘Let the beloved of the Lord rest secure in him,
    for he shields him all day long,
    and the one the Lord loves rests between his shoulders.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
About Joseph he said:
‘May the Lord bless his land
    with the precious dew from heaven above
    and with the deep waters that lie below;
speaker: Narrator

text:
with the best the sun brings forth
    and the finest the moon can yield;
speaker: Narrator

text:
with the choicest gifts of the ancient mountains
    and the fruitfulness of the everlasting hills;
speaker: Narrator

text:
with the best gifts of the earth and its fullness
    and the favour of him who dwelt in the burning bush.
Let all these rest on the head of Joseph,
    on the brow of the prince among his brothers.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
About Zebulun he said:
‘Rejoice, Zebulun, in your going out,
    and you, Issachar, in your tents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will summon peoples to the mountain
    and there offer the sacrifices of the righteous;
they will feast on the abundance of the seas,
    on the treasures hidden in the sand.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
About Gad he said:
‘Blessed is he who enlarges Gad’s domain!
    Gad lives there like a lion,
    tearing at arm or head.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He chose the best land for himself;
    the leader’s portion was kept for him.
When the heads of the people assembled,
    he carried out the Lord’s righteous will,
    and his judgments concerning Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
About Dan he said:
‘Dan is a lion’s cub,
    springing out of Bashan.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
About Naphtali he said:
‘Naphtali is abounding with the favour of the Lord
    and is full of his blessing;
    he will inherit southward to the lake.’
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The bolts of your gates will be iron and bronze,
    and your strength will equal your days.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘There is no one like the God of Jeshurun,
    who rides across the heavens to help you
    and on the clouds in his majesty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eternal God is your refuge,
    and underneath are the everlasting arms.
He will drive out your enemies before you,
    saying, “Destroy them!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Israel will live in safety;
    Jacob will dwell secure
in a land of grain and new wine,
    where the heavens drop dew.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blessed are you, Israel!
    Who is like you,
    a people saved by the Lord?
He is your shield and helper
    and your glorious sword.
Your enemies will cower before you,
    and you will tread on their heights.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses climbed Mount Nebo from the plains of Moab to the top of Pisgah, opposite Jericho. There the Lord showed him the whole land – from Gilead to Dan,
speaker: Narrator

text: all of Naphtali, the territory of Ephraim and Manasseh, all the land of Judah as far as the Mediterranean Sea,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Negev and the whole region from the Valley of Jericho, the City of Palms, as far as Zoar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to him, ‘This is the land I promised on oath to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob when I said, “I will give it to your descendants.” I have let you see it with your eyes, but you will not cross over into it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses the servant of the Lord died there in Moab, as the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: He buried him in Moab, in the valley opposite Beth Peor, but to this day no one knows where his grave is.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was a hundred and twenty years old when he died, yet his eyes were not weak nor his strength gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites grieved for Moses in the plains of Moab thirty days, until the time of weeping and mourning was over.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Joshua son of Nun was filled with the spirit of wisdom because Moses had laid his hands on him. So the Israelites listened to him and did what the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since then, no prophet has risen in Israel like Moses, whom the Lord knew face to face,
speaker: Narrator

text: who did all those signs and wonders the Lord sent him to do in Egypt – to Pharaoh and to all his officials and to his whole land.
speaker: Narrator

text: For no one has ever shown the mighty power or performed the awesome deeds that Moses did in the sight of all Israel.
speaker: Narrator
